titleStmt.title: Bird Harran

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: Once upon a time, there was a poor man. He was a shepherd who used to graze animals and eventually became the shepherd of a village.
He grazed the village's sheep and cows and received payment in return.
He received a fee from the villagers, who would give him something like a pension. He tended to the animals every day. One day, while he was grazing the sheep, he saw a bird.
"Al-ᵊmrēʕi," which means like the bird. He found it on the road and began playing with it. He grabbed a stick and started playing with the bird.
He pounced on the "ᵊmrēʕi" and grabbed it, saying, "I want to bury you to see how long you'll last."
He said, "I will leave you to die under the ground."
He dug the ground, placed the "mrēʕi" in it, and buried the bird.
Time passed, let's say. Since he grazed the animals every day in a different place—sometimes in the south, sometimes in the north, sometimes in the east, and so on.
Every day in a different place. One day, after four days, he went back to the first place where he used to graze the animals.
When he went there and looked, he said, "Wait, let me see if the 'mrēʕi' is alive or dead."
It is said that he opened the ground, and when he did, suddenly, the bird flew away.
The bird flew away and said, "Oh my God, it's been four days and you haven't died. This means there is a God who keeps you alive. Therefore, I will stop grazing the sheep."
He said, "I want to go and lie down at home," threw his stick, and went to his house.

When he got home, his wife said to him, "Ah, I see you've returned. Where are the sheep? Why didn't you leave them with the people?" He replied, "My Lord kept the 'mrēʕi' alive, so He will keep me alive too. I will no longer work."
The morning came, and the villagers brought their sheep and cows again, asking where the shepherd was so they could send him to tend to their animals. He replied, "I..."
His wife came to him and said, "Get up and go graze the animals. Take the people's livelihood and stake—their cows and sheep."
He said, "I have a Lord who kept the 'mrēʕi' alive, and He will keep me alive too. I will not go anymore!"
He placed a pillow for himself, covered himself with a blanket, and covered his head. He didn't want to get up or work, saying, "I will not work anymore!"

She came to him again and said, "Oh my God, this man has gone crazy! What has happened to him? Get up and go graze the animals. If you don’t graze and work, we won’t be able to eat, we won’t survive."
He said, "The Lord who kept the 'mrēʕi' alive will provide for me too." She replied, "This man has gone mad!"
She said, "I have no other solution." She took the stick, and the wife went out to graze the animals herself.
The next day, she came back and said to him, "Oh man, what has happened to you?"
He replied, "The Lord who kept the 'mrēʕi' alive will provide for me too."
When she goes to graze the animals, she collects everything she sees—sticks, firewood, and thorns, which are called "šammūṭ."
The "šammūṭ" has roots that cannot be pulled out easily. She said, "Tomorrow, I will bring an axe with me."
She said, "I will come and gather this 'šammūṭ.' I will collect firewood." This meant she was grazing the animals while simultaneously gathering firewood.
The next day, she took an axe with her and went.
She started digging up the "šammūṭ," and as she was digging, she found something resembling a vessel.
She examined it closely, and it was filled with gold. She thought to herself, "If I take this now to the villagers, they will share it with me."
So she decided to go and call her husband, who was sleeping at home. "Her husband," she thought.
She decided, "I will go and call him, and we will come together to take out the gold and become rich."
She went home and said, "Oh man, get up! I have found a vessel of gold. Come, let’s go and bring it."
He replied, "The Lord who kept the 'ᵊmrēʕi' alive will provide for me too. I will not go."

She said, "Oh man, please! Get up, where should I go? Who should I go to? Get up so we can go, take the gold, and become rich." He replied, "The Lord who kept the 'mrēʕi' alive will provide for me too. I will not go."
She had no other solution, so she went to her neighbor. Her neighbor was a man, and he was also...
You can say: "He was handsome, but God forbid, he was also lacking in morals."
She went to him and said, "Oh dear neighbor, I want to tell you something. Look, I found a vessel of gold in such and such a place."
She said, "And my husband, I don't know if he's gone crazy. I don't know what's happened to him. He's lost his mind—he won't move to go there."
He asked, "Will you come with me?" She replied, "Where is the vessel of gold?"
She said, "I found it in such and such a place. Come with me, and I will show you where it is, so we can go get it and share it between you and me."
He said, "Alright!" So they waited until the sun set, and nightfall came.
Yes, that was necessary. They said, "Wait, let’s wait until morning and go at dawn, when it's still dark."
They said, "We'll go get the vessel and return." When they left, it was still nighttime, let's say an hour before the dawn call to prayer.
They both started digging, and when they took out the vessel of gold and saw it, the night was so dark that one couldn’t see clearly.
They could only see the yellowish color, so they put it all in the bag and returned.
As they returned, the sun began to rise gradually, and it was becoming morning. He and the woman came back from that place.
They brought the bag with them. When they returned, she said to the man, "Let's go and share it."
He said, "Go away from here! You shameless woman! You want to share the gold with me? Listen, I will expose your honor if you don't leave!"
He said, "I will not give you this, the gold is mine." He betrayed her, and because she was a woman...
She said, "Do not touch my honor or anything else. Fine, I will go."
She went back to her home and reproached her husband. That man had taken the gold and gone to his house.
When he took the gold and left, she came to her husband and said, "Oh you, may God not bless you, oh man!"
"I found a vessel of gold, and our neighbor came, took it, and left. We went, got it, and he didn’t give it to me. He said, 'If you don't leave, I will tarnish your honor.'"

She said, "Oh you, may God... I don't know what to say!" He replied, "The Lord who kept the 'mrēʕi' alive will provide for me too." She then said, "May God cut you off and cut off the 'mrēʕi'!" That's what the wife said.
It is said that when the man who took the gold returned and opened what he had won, meaning the gold, from her neighbor...
When he opened the bag, it turned out that instead of gold, the bag was filled with wasps.
By God's will, the gold turned into wasps because he intended to harm the woman, threatening her honor.
He grabbed them and turned the gold into wasps—he transformed the gold into wasps.
He shouted, "Oh you daughter of a dog! She deceived me! She tricked me!"
He said, "Look how she caught me off guard, claiming she wanted the gold, but it was actually wasps all along. Now I will make them die, her and her husband!"
He said, "I must kill them. I will take the wasps to their house."
It is said that they had a hole like this—a hole—because their houses were made of mud and clay.
They had a hole like this, from their neighbors' house, a long opening leading from the man's house.
It is said that he brought the bag of wasps, placed it at the mouth of the opening, and sealed it shut so that the wasps would enter and kill them.
It is said that he continued to say, "The Lord who kept the 'mrēʕi' alive will provide for me too."
It is said that the gold began to fall at his feet—pieces of gold started to drop onto his feet—when he adjusted his position, and the gold that was in the bag had piled up at his feet.
He said, "The Lord who kept the 'mrēʕi' alive will provide for me too. Oh you daughter of a dog (You fool), didn’t I tell you? Look how the gold has come to me—it's come to my feet!"
